paddle (to paddle); make a canoe trip. Expression was used when a man and his helpers took food by canoe to his co-parent-in-law, father-in-law, or other male in-law (Suttles 1960: 300-1)

Lekwungen Word: 2. in 1911. They built five canoe houses facing the beach. From East to West, they were owned by Chief Michael Cooper, William Roberts, Jimmy Fraser, Jimmy Johnny (Father of Sophie Mishael), and Alex Peter with Jack Dick. The

here; be here; be close to (the speaker)

seal. Phoca vitulina. The rights to sealing rocks were oened by individual families. Seals might be clubbed on the rocks or netted or harpooned in a the water by a small crew (Barnett 1955:99, 251; Suttles 1952:10)
cod, (Gadidae) , ling cod. Cod were speared in the summer and early fall, and sun-dried or smoked. Oil was saved to pour on ceremonial fires to increase the blaze (Gunther 1927:199; Stern 1934:49)

Lekwungen Word: 2. could be ceremonially distributed to enhance the prestige of the giver (Suttles 1960:301). Food was not considered wealth, but a surplus might be given away with the expectation that wealth would be received in return

Cowichan hero and warrior from q̓ʷəmiʔíqən who had tewnty wives. In one tale he is beheaded by a runaway slave, in another he is strangled by one of his wives. It was said no man could kill him.
stony; be covered with pebbles; be in a stony place; beach
Cowichan hero who defeated the kɫekʷət people when they attached the Cowichan and Songish, probably at Lake Cowichan. The name may mean "he is very powerful".
Placename: South SaanichTerritory north of x̣ʷsepsəm (Xwsepsum) and south of Saanich. Also spelled Tsuli'lhchu
thank with wealth; especially to thank a co-parent-in-law for his gift of food by presenting him with wealth.
co-parent-in-law after the death of one member of the married pare of offspring: "those who weep together"
rotting; starting to rot or spoil
Placename: This approximate village site belonged to the Ts’angus people. They were said by Sophie Mishael and Ned Williams, to have lived in the bay on Albert Head.
rotten, to be rotten, be spoiled, wormy
put it up; put it on; put it upon
thank, to thank someone; thank with wealth
November, mid-winter: "shining ice on the ground"
stinging nettles. Boiled nettles were fed to women in labour to ease childbirth; nets for trappng birds were made of nettle twine.
maker; worker; diligent (someone who works well)

Placename: Territory to east of xwsepsum lands, in what is today̓s Oak Bay. Also spelled Chekonein.

Lekwungen Word: 2. of their homes being at the bottom of a hill. This area is called McNeill Bay or Shoal Bay today. This is the name of the family which signed the Douglas Treaty (spelled Chilkowitch on the treaty). Chief číɫəm (spelled
English Translation: 3. Chayth-lum on the treaty)of this family was the highest Songhees chief.

Lekwungen Word: 2. Klallam First Nation. They are now called Scia’new). The name most likely comes from a word meaning fish. The Lək̓wángən word is sčeenəxʷ (schenuhw). There is also a reefnet site with the same name, to the east of the mouth

pitch, resin. Used as chewing gum and for illumination and startig fires durig ceremonials (Barnett t3)

surf scoter or white-winged scoter, black duck, the largest scoter

childbirth, labour pains. During childbirth, the mother is secluded in a hut or behind a blanket partition in the house. She is assisted by a female doctor who gives her medications to ease her contractions.
most; superlative state or condition (best; most; worst; oldest; youngest; etc.)

Placename (kohweechela): Now called Tod Island, used to be called Jimmy Chicken Island and was owned by Jimmy Chicken, Sophie Mishael's grandfather. This the first island near the mouth of Bowker creek in Oak Bay.

English Translation: 2. launched across a field toward a goal.

English Translation: 2. Juan and Henry Islands. There was another location at Becher Bay at East Sooke, similarly named məq’a’as
be full; satiated; be full (of food)

English Translation: 2. the reef net site at Beechey Head was called Maqʷa’as. See entry for Nəxʷkʷic̓ec̓əŋ (Nuhwkwits̓ets̓ung).

English Translation: 2. reefnet site with the similar name of Nuhwkwits’ets’ung off Beechey Head.
have one's hair oiled; be annointed with oil

Placename: currently called Mount Douglas, the highest mountain in cəliʔɫčə (South Saanich) territory. means "white head". This was traditionally a sacred mountain.
mat, rug, floor mat. Cedar bark, tule, and rush mats covered temporary summer house frames, sleeping benches, and stored food; were sat on during meals (Barnett 1955:121-2; Stern 1934:92)

Lekwungen Word: 1. Placename: "Place of Rushes" , roughly where the Empress Hotel stands today. The valley leading to Beacon hill from Pshay at the Inner Harbour was very moist and a good place to collect rushes used to make sleeping mats,
English Translation: 2. tents, and sails. Edward Joe said people used to bring canoe loads of gravel (presumably to build pathways) because the ground was so muddy.
bucking the tide, go into the wind
blow it; blow on something; inflate
forked stick for cooking fish over a fire; stick for barbecueing
steam; be steamed. Meat, fish, and plant foods were placed on layer of leaves in pit lined with hot rocks, covered and steamed for one to three days (Barnett 1955:60-1; Gunther 1927:209).

Lekwungen Word: 1. Placename: "place of the ghost" literally means to be haunted or touched by a ghost or an owl. Inland end of Gorge waterway. This was the name for Craigflower Creek which used to be called Deadman River. This river was a Coho
English Translation: 2. stream, with fish coming all the way up the Gorge, or Q’umasung waterway. Songhees Elder Frank George mentions the salmon and herring that would come up the waterway.
May; "when camas is collected"; dig for camas

Lekwungen Word: 4. the increased development of downtown Victoria, to move. In 1911 they moved to the current reserve off Admirals road. Chief Thomas tells the story of how James Douglas spoke with his ancester Si’sunuq, explaining how the
English Translation: 5. Whites would continue to pour in. At that point Si'sunuq moved his people to Qallu, the current Esquimalt reserve.
smoking; a lot of smoke (from a fire)
Placename: Penelakut Spit on Kuper Island
Placename: small island just of the coast, west of Cadboro Bay. Also spelled Bukkaynung (Grant Keddie 2003 p.54)
cone of pine or fir; acorn
Placename: Puyallup, Washington, where hops are picked
take it out (of a container), bring it out

Placename: Traditional village site where the Esquimalt Nation reserve is today. Translated as "spring water gushing down the beach". Unsure of etymology, may be related to x̣ʷəq̓íləŋ meaning to drift downstream.
Placename: area on the southern shore of the mouth of Cadboro Bay. Also spelled Kakhalaang (Grant Keddie 2003 p.54).
recently; a while ago, a little while ago

Lekwungen Word: 1. Placename: The people from this village at Witty’s Beach later moved to Becher (Chowits’en) Bay. The Klallam chief Tl’eixum (ƛ̓eyx̣əm-spelled Tly-a-hum on the Douglas treaty for the Quqay’uqun) who according to the treaty,
English Translation: 2. was a descendant of the Quqay’uqun (Duff 151:4).
crab apple; Malus fusca (Crab apple wood was burned and live charcoal was carried in clam shells on long trips to provide fire (Stern 1934:55).
devil’s club; Opolopanax horridus (With spines removed, the stems are charred and mixed with grease or face cream for black face paint).

Lekwungen Word: 1. tan hides, to tan hides. Elk and deer skins were dressed by women, who soaked them in water and scraped off the hair. Hides were then washed, rubbed with deer brains and fat, and smoked. Finished skins were made into shirts,
English Translation: 2. moccasins, and storage bags (Barnett 1955:125; Gunther 1927:219; Stern 1934:32).
dancer’s headdress (conical headdress is made of shredded cedar bark, human hair, or, for novices, wool; the peak is decorated with eagle feathers).
cause to speak together, to each other; cause to discuss
tell from a distance; speak from far away

English Translation: hold; rock in one's arms (as a baby)
talking; talk a lot; be talkative
scissors (have example recordings of both q̓c̓ə́ʔkʷən and q̓ə́c̓əʔkʷən

skate; ray; Rajiformes spp. Skate were speared as they came toward
shore; stomachs were cut out and remainder was boiled; fins might be grilled
(Gunther 1927:209; Stern 1934:51).
bites it on purpose; he/she/they bite it on purpose
whale (generic term). Whaling was not common among Lenkwungen people. Whale might be harpooned by a seal hunter or utilized when it came ashore dead (Barnett 1955:92; Suttles 1952:11).

Lekwungen Word: 2. the rapids near the Admirals street bridge. People would dive into the water there, seeking spirit power. They would carry a big rock with them to sink them to the bottom. While underwater, Q̓əm̓asəŋ would take mercy on them
English Translation: 3. and grant them the powers they were seeking.
late, be late; slow, be slow

Lekwungen Word: 1. boy's puberty. When a boy̓s voice began to change, he underwent rigorous training, including fasting, bathing in cold water, and scrubbing his body with twigs, and endured other physical hardships to prepare himself for
English Translation: 2. supernatural experiences leading to the acquisition of a spirit helper (Barnett 1955:77, 143; Stern 1934:18}.

grill, roast. Smelt, flounder, skate fins, dried salmon, mussels, and fern roots were grilled on sticks over an open fire

Placename: Somenos (Samuna'), Cowichan Village at Duncan

Placename: This name for Willow’s Beach refers to the driftwood that washes up on the beach (see čəŋéɬč- oak tree). Ned Williams’ father, ƛ̓’yəc̓kiʔnəm (Tl'iuts’ki’num, used to live in a Bighouse near here.
peninsula; point of land; arrow point
body; soul; spirit; animate or living part of a person or animal

English Translation: 3. to throw a harpoon, and made him “boss over all the seals”. White settlers cut up the rock and used it for grave stones, and that’s why there are so few seals there today.
take something up from the water
left; left hand; left side of body
Placename: traditional name for Chatham Island
really (that which is really, very or truly something)
twins. Birth of twins is auspicious (good luck) as both parents and children are thought to have special supernatural power (Barnett 1955:135; Gunther 19~7:237: Stern 1934:14-15).
Placename: Village in the Oak Bay area south of Cadboro Bay
ride (travel upon something, such as a horse); straddle(?)
a big run of fish; lots of fish
smart, one who is clever, know how to
Placename: area in Teečəmitsə territory near where Royal Roads University is today.
stick; short stick carried by an initiated spirit dancer

Lekwungen Word: 1. Placename: area across the harbour from Esquimalt reserve, translated as "mouldy beach". When harvesting clams at this small beach inside Rodd Point, the people would turn over rocks which were moldy, or covered in algae on
English Translation: 2. the bottoms. Sophie Mishael and Ned Williams remembered houses there that belonged to people who were not Esquimalt (Xwsepsum).
straight, correct, right, have form or shape

Lekwungen Word: 1. Placename: Village site and northern end of Esquimalt Harbour, translated as "Stones with green moss hanging from them". Jimmy Fraser recalled there being a village “where the sawmill was”. Wilson Duff thinks this was on the

English Translation: Placename: the mouth of Victoria Harbour leading up to q̓əmasəŋ, near ogden point
Placename: Chemainus. People of Chemainus Bay

club, war club. A paddle-shaped club of stone, bone or heavy wood was the principal weapon for close combat. Each was about one foot long and attached to the wrist with a short thong (Barnett 1955:269; Gunther 1927:268).

woodpecker (pileated woodpecker). (A common spirit helper for canoe-builders
(Barnett 1955:111); the shaman often wore woodpecker feathers in his
hair (Barnett 1955:149).

tidy, to tidy; put in order; straighten up
she; her (person is visible to the speaker)
right, right hand, right side of body

Lekwungen Word: 1. teasing wool. An early step in preparation of wool for weaving to be or knitting. After the raw wool has been washed, it is separated by hand into small clumps so that foreign material. (leaves, twigs, dirt) will either fall
English Translation: 2. out or be more easily removed
Proper name of owner of Bighouse near Qallə village, father of Edward Joe, former Esquimalt Chief.
play; play games; play with toys; make fun; ridicule; entertain; perform
go across; go over; from one place to another
give gifts reciprocally, in return (as, between bride's family and groom̓s family)

Lekwungen Word: 1. Placename: This name refers to the people who lived in Sooke Bay. A T’sou-ke legend tells of a copper box that dropped from heaven and landed just east of Billings Spit (the peninsula where skʷáʔnəŋəs village sat). Four men
English Translation: 2. emerged from the box; these became the ancestors of the T’sou-ke, Elwah, Malahat, and Duncan peoples.
dog fish; Sgualus suckleyi (traditionally not eaten but their oil is prized for medical purposes. It is rubbed on a woman in labour to ease the contractions and on the newborn infant (Stern 1934:14)
Placename: Andrew's Bay (on San Juan Island)
Placename: a tiny island to the west of kʷəw̓xʷíčəlaʔ (Grant Keddie 2003 p.54)
acquisition, a discovery; that which is found
bathe; give a bath (she bathed him)

Lekwungen Word: 1. Placename: Thlowuck. This may not be a traditional Placename, and if it is, the spelling is most likely questionable. This name is taken from the T’sou-ke (Soke) Douglas treaty. The treaty describes the western boundary of
English Translation: 2. the territory as “Three Rivers two bays beyond Thlowuck”. This location may be called Point Shirringham today, a few kilometers east of French Beach..
live there; reside in that place; be there (at a place distant from the speaker)
bone game; A guessing game, teams of players guessing over distinctively marked pieces of bone. Spectators bet on outcome of each attempt to guess.
cedar bark (soft inner bark used for weaving)

comb; a comb : Were made of yew or maple wood; pubescent girl was required to scratch
her head with a comb, rather than with her fingers.
herring; Clupeidae. Fish and their eggs were important as food; fish also used for baiting trolling hooks. Caught mainly in late spring with aid of herring rake.

someone who is naked; someone who has been raped

that you bring down (to the beach)

mat; wall-mat (often made from bear grass)

English Translation: bunch of monsters; beasts; powerful mythical animals
preserved fish eggs (Fish roe was smoke-dried and stored in a deer paunch (Gunther 1927:206).
lose game; defeat; war that is lost

Lekwungen Word: 4. x̣ʷix̣ʷəqʷ (Xwixwuqʷ) lived and died in the southern village, located where the marina is today. The people from Cadboro Bay were familiar to the Semiahmoo because the Snge’qu would visit Birch Bay, between Bellingham and
English Translation: 5. White Rock, every year for deer and clams. The Semiahmoo woman that told this to Suttles referred to the Cadboro Bay people as xʷəlxʷələqʷ (Hwul-hwuluqʷ).
octopus, devilfish (gathered at low tide from beneath rocks. Were boiled or steamed and eaten or were used as bait for fish (Gunther 1927:198; Stern 1934:51).
mythical sea creature; great fisherman who is very lucky

Lekwungen Word: 1. Placename: for Discovery Island. Also names the people whose territory included Discovery and Chatham Islands (Hill-Tout 1907:307). There is a secret spring on the island where people used to go to receive their power. But it
English Translation: 2. has never been found. For many years sheep lived on the island and it is thought they must have found the spring in order to have survived.

Placename: Squamish; people whose winter villages were located along the rivers at the head of Howe Sound. They joined the late summer aggregation of Salish at the mouth of the Fraser River (Barnett 1955:31).
fir; white fir; grand fir. Also pronounced sqʷəwməyʔyəwqs
coiled; something coiled (like rope or a snake)

dead person; nearly dead; or paralyzed

roast; cooked; a piece of roasted food
fine, that which is fine; soft

Lekwungen Word: 1. wolf (Wolf's superior hunting ability can be conferred on humans who obtain his favour in a supernatural encounter. Hunters of land mammals became wolves at death. Because of the mythological association, wolf meat was

1. Placename: Wolf den; name of village on peninsual at south end of Plumber Bay overlooking Esquimalt reserve. The name for the tiny island or peninsula across from the harbour. Wolves used to come right down to the beach here.

English Translation: hero; brave person with powers; mythical character
what's the matter?; what was done?; what happened?
behind ones back; be behind someone

you folks; second person plural pronoun (subject)

backpack; device for carrying on your back
Placename: territory in what is now known as James Bay neighbourhood of Victoria BC.
similar; one which is like this; how it is; be as it is

swan; swan's down; (A pregnant woman might be fed swan fat to aid in labor (Stern 1934:14).

Lekwungen Word: 1. Placename: This is the name of small spring that runs out from the beach into the sea by the eastern side of the mouth of Becher Bay. The fishing is good here because it said the salmon come here to drink from the fresh
English Translation: 2. spring. The name, scratch refers comes from a rock behind the spring which has several scratches on it.

Lekwungen Word: 1. fern. Fern leaves were used to line roasting pits and were ritually prominent in ceremonies centering on girls at time of puberty. Fern roots were eaten. Families owned specific beds of fern plants (Gunther 1927:197. 209;

Lekwungen Word: 3. the name might be derived from x̣ʷay̓məɫəɫ (hwa’yumulh) "all lying dead". There is a story about a famine. Then some whales swam into the harbour and died. The people came down and slaughtered the whales, providing the
English Translation: 4. village with meat. It is not certain whether this story is the reason for the name of the village all lay dying.
Indian ice-cream; pudding-like confection made of crushed soapberries, water, and sugar whipped with a bundle of maple-leaves
goose with red nose; probably Anser albifrons
costume, regalia worn by new spirit dancers.
bathe; give a bath; cleanse (bathe her)
lazy people. Considered the worst fault in a person
forced; be forced to; be told to do something
lazy person -very lazy. Considered the worst fault in a person

want; a wish; a need; a desire; liking; loving

calm; be calm; that which is smooth; soft
Placename: At the base of what is now called Goldstream river.
Proper name of Sophie Mishael's grandfather, Jimmy Chickens, who was impressed by the Spaniards and forced to serve on a ship. He escaped after three years and returned to his village.
standing; standing for a long time

English Translation: dizzy; become overcome with dizzines; being spun
Placename: portage connecting to Esquimalt Harbour at Thetis Cove to Gorge waterway. Translated as "drag over a narrow place".

at the place where; distant place

Placename: This Klallam village inside Edze spit, where Port Angeles is today, was probably the home village of chief ƛ̓eyx̣əm (Tl’eixum) and stəteqinəm (Sutuqinum).
Placename: Means flying dust, this is the name for Oak Bay, and the southwestern shore near the marina. The word was also pronounced as Shehwung and translated as fog.

Aboriginal person, people who came before

Lekwungen Word: 1. Placename: "Place of war" is at the point of land between Oak Bay and McNeill Bay. As well as being a village, this was a sacred site where people would hang their babies’ cradles, like P’aluts’us in the Victoria inner
English Translation: 2. harbour. The water in front of this point are so swift “that people passing in canoes were not able to speak” (Duff file 151:26).
wand; stick with supernatural power which a shaman used in healing rituals. The wands were passed over the patient's body to draw out the source of his ailment.
Placename: Village site on northern side of Ten Mile point of peninsula in Haro Straight, North of Cordoba Bay. Translated as "Point of cracking sea urchins".
Placename: for Elk Lake. "drifting along", named for the island.
drift downstream; drift with the current
Placename: Means pussy willow. This is the name for the area that includes Ross Bay and Clover Point. It was said to have been too rough to land canoes here.
